issues.description: The problem statement (UML and explicit note) requires the Animal constructor and the name getter/setter to have protected visibility (UML uses '#' and the text explicitly instructs to implement the name getter and setter with protected visibility). The reference solution implements these members as public (Animal.java: public Animal(String), public String getName(), public void setName(...)). This is a structural visibility mismatch: students following the problem text will implement protected accessors/constructor, while the solution exposes them as public. This discrepancy can confuse students about the intended encapsulation and grading expectations, and it diverges from the UML specification in the problem.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the solution match the problem specification (and UML): change the Animal constructor and the getName()/setName(...) methods to protected in Animal.java. Concretely, replace 'public Animal(String name)' with 'protected Animal(String name)', and replace the public getter/setter signatures with protected visibility. Alternatively, if public visibility was intended, update the problem statement/UML to indicate public visibility to avoid confusion.
